title-group.article-title: A review of multiscale composite manufacturing and challenges

article-meta.aff: High-Performance Materials Institute, Florida A&M University – Florida State University, College of Engineering, Tallahassee, FL, USA

author-notes.corresp: Okenwa I Okoli, High-Performance Materials Institute, Florida A&M University – Florida State University, College of Engineering, Tallahassee, FL, USA. Email: okoli@eng.fsu.edu

abstract.p: As the utilization of advanced composites in structural applications grows, the need for improving their through-thickness properties becomes imperative. Although the behavior of composite laminates under structural and thermal loads has received much attention with their growth in safety critical structures, more effort needs to go into selectively improving their electrical and thermal conductivities. Additionally, the ability to manufacture composite structures that can inherently monitor their own health will be exceedingly beneficial. This paper provides an overview of advances made towards multiscale composite manufacturing. Multiscale composites, especially with the use of carbon nanotubes, have been sought to provide enhanced structural (through-thickness) properties and increased electrical and thermal conductivities. This report will review the state of art in the manufacturing of multiscale composites, their scalability, and their inherent potential for multifunctionality. Current techniques mostly result in the application of carbon nanotubes throughout the entire laminates, rather than in selected areas. Subsequently, one of the main barriers, to the widespread use of carbon nanotube-applied composites, is an efficient mass-producible manufacturing process. This paper attempts to highlight the current knowledge gaps in this critical area of composites manufacturing.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Advanced composite materials have seen increased applications over the last three decades culminating in the recent launch of the Boeing 787 in which composites make up over 50% of its overall weight. As more is required of engineered structures, designers are looking increasingly towards tailorable materials.1 The goal of manufacturing an all composite commercial aircraft will be more feasible if engineers could tailor material properties in different sections. For instance, electrical conductivity could be increased in critical sections to allow for lightening strike protection without the use of metals.2 Thermal behavior may be similarly tuned.

Multiscale composite materials have typically been manufactured by the introduction of nanomaterials into polymer resin systems and then introduced to a mold filled with macro reinforcements such as glass fibers or carbon fibers. Figure 1 illustrates the concept of a multiscale composite employing single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) and traditional fibers.4 In some instances, the nanomaterials are grown directly on the carbon fibers, and the resin is introduced to the multiscale reinforcements.2,5,6 The macro reinforcements act as in-plane load carriers, whilst the nanomaterials primarily affect the through thickness properties. Composite materials utilizing nanocomponents have shown profound enhancements of various material properties. In terms of nanoparticle incorporation into multiscale composites, enhanced tensile and flexural properties have been observed.7 In the cases where the nano materials are carbon nanotubes (CNTs), the electrical and thermal properties of the resulting composites are greatly enhanced.4,8 Figure 1.
Concepts of multiscale reinforcement composites.3

All advantages considering a major issue inhibiting the utilization of multiscale composites is their scalability and limitations in the current manufacturing methods. Once nanomaterials are introduced to resin systems, their viscosities can significantly increase to the point where they are not infusible.9 Researchers then resort to open-mold techniques such as hand lay-up to manufacture these laminates. Others have grown the CNTs directly on carbon fibers.5,6 Both scenarios present difficulties in scalability. As such, many researchers report on efforts using rather small-sized specimens. Other issues include the ability to effectively disperse the CNTs within the resin systems to allow for their reduced agglomeration and efficient load transfer through good resin-CNT interfacial bonding.10–16 The desire to embody all of these characteristics into efficiently scalable multiscale composites drives the initiative to create materials and supporting processes capable of tailoring a single product to encompass all these factors.

sec.title: Multiscale composites
sec.p: This paper presents a review of various types of CNTs and their application to composite materials. The focus will be on harnessing the heralded attributes of these nanomaterials in the creation of multiscale, multifunctional components. Available techniques for the manufacture of the said multiscale laminates will be reviewed and evaluated for effectiveness in manufacturing real components. Available models for predicting the resulting material properties will be evaluated.

sec.title: CNTs
sec.p:
Carbon nanostructures can be defined as carbon materials that are produced such that either their size or their structure is controlled at the nanometer scale (less than 100 nm).8 CNTs are structures of nano-dimensions made up of rolled sheets of graphite. There are three primary ways in which a sheet of graphite is rolled up to form a tube: zigzag, chiral, and armchair are the names given to the different types. Essentially, the graphite sheet can be rolled along one axis of the symmetry yielding either a zigzag tube or an armchair tube. Another way is to roll up the graphite sheet in an opposing direction that differs from an axis of symmetry. By doing this, a chiral nanotube, in which the equivalent atoms of each unit cell are aligned on a spiral, is obtained. Along with the chiral angle, the circumference of the cylinder can also be varied in this manner. Nanotubes are classified as zigzag, armchair, or chiral tubes varying primarily in diameters as depicted in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Schematic diagram showing how a hexagonal sheet of graphene is rolled to form a nanotube with different morphologies ((a): armchair; (b): zigzag; (c): chiral).13,17,18

The packing of the carbon hexagons in the graphitic sheets defines a chiral vector (m, n) and angle, and the indices of the vector determine the morphology of the nanotube. Thus, when m-n/3 is an integer, the resulting structure is metallic; otherwise, it is a semiconducting nanotube.19 Variations in the rolled configurations or chiralities yield different properties to the nanotubes. For instance, the electronic properties of an armchair nanotube are metallic; however, the electronic properties of zigzag and chiral nanotubes are semiconducting.20

The nanotubes tubes may be single-walled (SWNT), double-walled (DWNT), or multiwalled (MWNT) as illustrated in Figure 3 computer animated image and in Figure 4 transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image. Figure 3.
Structures of single-walled carbon nanotube (SWNT), double-walled carbon nanotube (DWNT), and multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWNT). Figure 4.
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of different carbon nanotubes (CNTs) ((a) single-walled carbon nanotube (SWNTs), (b) multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWNTs) with different layers of 5, 2, and 7).13,17,18

The Young’s modulus of a CNT is over 1 TPa. It has an estimated tensile strength of over 150 GPa, translating to being a hundred times stronger than steel, though three to five times lighter. Utilizing the imagery of the computer animated structure of Figure 3, Figure 4 can be more easily differentiated. Figure 4(a) and (b) are actual TEM images of CNTs; the first (a) showing SWNT, DWNT, and MWNTs intertwined with one another, and the second (b) depicting the different layers of MWNTs, from two layers (DWNT) in the middle to five (on the left) and seven (on the right) layers MWNT.

Many researchers using carbon nanofibers (CNFs) and CNTs to manufacture polymer nanocomposites (PNCs) have reported mechanical, electrical, and thermal property improvements as a result of the nanoparticle additives to the matrix.19,21–29 Studies have shown that chemically modifying the surfaces of nanoparticles helps disperse the CNTs better in polymer matrices and results in improved physical properties.30 Thus, enhancing the PNC matrix properties should lead to property enhancements in the fiber-reinforced composite (FRC) system and may result in a composite with the potential to perform in a multifunctional capacity.

Fundamental aspects of CNTs. Particle size, shape, orientation, and volume content of constituent materials on the composite properties have various influences, such as strengthening capability and conductivity.31 Figure 5 is a graph showing the surface-to-volume ratio for a variety of CNTs with different aspect ratios (length/diameter) as a function of the diameter. Figure 5.
Ratio of particle surface and volume for spherical and fibrous particles as a function of the particle diameter.32

In addition, the same ratio is shown for spherical nanoparticles like fumed silica (FS) and carbon black (CB). For comparison, conventional reinforcements like glass balls (GB), glass and carbon fibers (GF, CF) are shown. In the double logarithmic scale of Figure 5, the surface/volume ratio decreases linearly as the particle size increases. Elaborating further, a small volume content of nanoparticles provides huge surface areas, which in turn enhances the nucleation of polymer crystals in thermoplastic materials33 or the cross-linking density in thermosets. This increases the mechanical properties due to the change in the polymer morphology. Therefore, the advantage of nanoparticle reinforcement is the enhancement of the polymer morphology because of the introduction of reinforcing nanomaterials attributing high mechanical properties.

One of the fundamentals for acquiring the mechanical properties of a CNT/resin/fiber multiscale composite is to compute the material properties of the CNT/resin composite. The Halpin–Tsai equations are a set of empirical relationships that enable the property of a composite material to be broken down and expressed. This is articulated in terms of the properties of the matrix and reinforcing phases together with their proportions and geometry. The Halpin–Tsai equation that yields the tensile modulus of a nanocomposite can be expressed as:34–36 (1)ENC=[381+2(lNTdNT)nLVNT1-nLVNT581+2nDVNT1-nDVNT]Eepoxy where (2)nL=((ENT/Eepoxy)-(dNT4t)(ENT/Eepoxy)+(lNT2t)) (3)nD=((ENT/Eepoxy)-(dNT4t)(ENT/Eepoxy)+(lNT2t)) and where E, lNT, dNT, VNT, and t represent the tensile modulus, the length and outer diameter of the nanotubes, nanotube volume fraction, and thickness of graphite layer (0.34 nm), respectively.

sec.title: Multiscale composites
sec.p:
Composite material behavior is quite different from modern conventional materials being utilized in aerospace, civil, military, and commercial industries. Composite materials are able to offer similar or better mechanical and structural properties than their metallurgical predecessors, and at a lower weight. Traditional FRCs have shown great promise in structural applications due to their high stiffness-to-weight ratios and their ease of processing. Nonetheless, although their in-plane, fiber-dominant properties make them desirable, their through-thickness or z-axis properties are matrix-dominant and have limited their use.37,38 As seen in Figure 6(a)–(c), matrix (polymer resin)-dominant areas are prevalent throughout a composite part or laminate. The resin first engulfs the fiber bundles and then proceeds to permeate the individual fibers, inter-tow, and intra-tow. During saturation the polymer, resin-enriched areas succumb to matrix-dominant properties. The addition of CNTs (Figure 6(d)) increases the matrix properties structurally (mechanically) and conductively (electrically and thermally). Figure 6.
A schematic depicting the characteristics of a typical unsaturated-flow pattern within the dual-scale fiber performs, and highlighting the delayed impregnation of the fiber tows,39 intra-tow cross section of the fiber strands and polymer matrix: (b) glass fiber and (c) carbon fiber,4 (d) multiscale stage setup (intra-tow).43

FRCs have found extensive use in aerospace, automotive, construction, and recreational equipment industrial sectors; however, their previously stated limitations have inhibited them from reaching their full potential.40 The incorporation of nanoparticles in polymers opens a new arena where polymer matrices can be tailored to optimize specific properties just as fiber orientation is used to optimize conventional advanced composites. For instance, nanoparticles, such as CNFs and CNTs, have been recognized as promising nanoconstituents in PNCs due to their aforementioned property enhancements. Nonetheless, their incorporation into fiber-filled resin systems presents practical challenges that need to be overcome.

sec.title: Nanoconstituents and multiscale composites
sec.p: Modifying the fiber reinforcement constituent within an FRC system by grafting41,42 or electrophoretically depositing43 nanoparticles onto the fiber can serve as a way to develop multifunctional composites. Thus, multiscale fiber reinforced composites (M-FRCs) can be manufactured by either modifying the resin matrix or fiber reinforcement. For example, Qiu et al. developed epoxy/CNT/glass fiber M-FRCs and reported a 16% and 27% increase in tensile strength and modulus, respectively, for their 1 wt% functionalized CNT M-FRC sample.43 They dispersed surface-modified CNTs into a resin matrix and pre-impregnated their unidirectional glass fiber preforms prior to vacuum-assisted resin infusion molding (VaRIM) fabrication.

In studies that have modified the fiber reinforcement, researchers have reported improved mechanical and thermomechanical properties.44 For instance, Bekyarova et al. studied the effect of electrophoretically dispersing (EPD) 0.25 wt% functionalized CNTs onto carbon fiber preforms followed by fabrication of M-FRCs using a VaRIM process. They observed a 27% enhancement in interlaminar shear strength (ILSS). The 27% increase in ILSS is suggestive of improved matrix-dominant properties in the M-FRC. The mechanical property enhancements in both studies were attributed to the use of functionalized CNTs, which enhanced their dispersion throughout the polymer matrix and strengthened CNT-polymer matrix interactions. In a study investigating the dimensional stability of epoxy/CNT/glass-fiber M-FRC, other researchers reported that their 1 wt% M-FRC sample exhibited a 25% reduction in coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) relative to their neat sample.5 The CTE reduction was suggestive of well-dispersed CNTs throughout the matrix of the M-FRC. In the same research, they reported an 11°C reduction in the glass transition temperature (Tg) of their 1 wt% M-FRC sample relative to the neat FRC sample. The Tg reduction suggests that the cross-link density decreases due to interference of the functional groups on the CNTs during curing. As a result, the presence of the functionalized CNTs disrupts the optimized epoxy resin-curing agent ratio in the curing reaction.21

sec.title: Micromechanics for nanocomposites using computational modeling
sec.p: The modeling and simulation methods on a molecular level usually employ atoms, molecules, or their conglomeration as the basic units considered. The two widely used molecular scale methods are molecular dynamics (MD) and Monte Carlo (MC) simulation which allow for the prediction of the time evolution of a system of interacting particles (e.g., atoms, molecules, granules, etc.) and estimates the relevant physical properties.45,46 Specifically, MD generates such information as atomic positions, velocities, and forces from which the macroscopic properties (e.g., pressure, energy, heat capacities) can be derived by means of statistical mechanics. The MC technique, also called Metropolis method,47 is a stochastic method that uses random numbers to generate a sample population of the system from which one can calculate the properties of interest. MC provides only the information on equilibrium properties (e.g., free energy, phase equilibrium), different from MD, which gives non-equilibrium as well as equilibrium properties. Dissipative particle dynamics (DPD) was originally developed by Hoogerbrugge;48 it can simulate both Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluids, including polymer melts and blends, on microscopic length and time scales. Like MD, DPD is a particle-based method. However, its basic unit is not a single atom or molecule but a molecular assembly (i.e., a particle).49,50

Mechanical properties of nanostructured materials may be predicted by a select set of computational methods. These modeling methods cover a wide range of length and time scales. Figure 7 shows the relationship of specific modeling techniques in computational mechanics and computation chemistry. Figure 7.
Diagram of material modeling techniques.51

For the smallest length and time scales, computational chemistry techniques, such as Ab initio and MD52 are primarily used to determine atomic 12 structures, using the first-principles theory. Specific micromechanical techniques contain the Eshelby approach, the Mori-Tanaka method,53–55 and the Halpin-Tsai method.56,57 The Mori-Tanaka method originated from a method of calculating the average internal stress in the matrix of a material containing inclusions with transformation strain.53

In the Mori–Tanaka method, Odegard et al. state the assumption that only the two phases exist (matrix and reinforcement), and they are perfectly bonded to each other. Though the Mori–Tanaka approach has been used to correctly predict overall properties of composites, it has been shown to only be applicable when the reinforcements are on the micrometer-scale level, or higher. At the nanometer level, the reinforcement and adjacent polymer region is not accurately described as consisting of just two phases, thus the Mori–Tanaka model is not expected to perform well for nanostructured reinforcements. The effective interface model was used to predict the elastic properties of a composite with effective particles that have an interface of the same spherical shape as the effective particle in Figure 8. The effective interface has a finite size and models the region immediately surrounding the spherical reinforcement, which is commonly referred to as an interphase or an interaction zone. The micromechanical model used for this was developed for composites with two phase particles.58 Figure 8.
Schematic illustration of Mori-Tanaka and effective interface micromechanics approaches.55

For this effective interface method, which is derived from the Mori-Tanaka model, the bulk elastic-stiffness tensor of the composite containing the isotropic constituents follows this equation: (4)C=Cm+[(cp+ci)(Ci-Cm)Tpi +cp(Cp-Ci)Tp]x[cmI+(Cp+Ci)Tpi]-1 where the uppercase terms indicate tensor quantities, cp and cm are the effective particle and matrix volume fractions, respectively, Cp and Cm are the stiffness tensors of the effective particle and matrix, respectively, where ci and Ci are the volume fraction and stiffness tensor for the interface, respectively, I is the identity tensor, and Tp and Tpi are the dilute strain-concentration tensor of the effective particles, and is given by: (5)Tp=I-Sp[Sp+(Cp-Cm)-1Cm]-1 (6)Tpi=I-Sp{cici+cp[Sp+(Cp-Cm)-1Cm]-1 +cici+cp[Sp+(Cp-Cm)-1Cm]-1} where Sp is the Eshelby tensor.59 For spherical effective particle and an isotropic matrix, the components of the Eshelby tensor are60 given by (7)S1111=S2222=S3333=7-5v15(1-v)S1122=S2233=S3311=S1133=S2211=S3322=5v-115(1-v)S1212=S2323=S3131=4-5v15(1-v)

Similar to the Mori–Tanaka model, the effective interface model assumes that the phases are perfectly bonded to each other. However, the region that physically exists between the surface of the particle and the polymer matrix that has the bulk polymer molecular structure can be considered as an effective interface.

Halpin-Tsai equations are on the basis of a self-consistent micromechanics method.56 For the largest length and time scales, computational mechanics, finite element method, and boundary element method are used to determine the mechanical behavior of materials and engineering structures.9,51,61–63 A continuum-based elastic micromechanics model was developed by Odegard et al.55 for silica nanoparticle/polyimide composites with various nanoparticle/polyimide interfacial treatments. The micromechanics model incorporated the molecular structures of the nanoparticle, polyimide, and interfacial regions that included an effective interface between the polyimide and effective nanoparticle with properties and dimensions, which were determined using the results of MD simulations. Utilizing modeling and simulation methods, multiscale manufacturing processes can be evaluated and simulated to emphasize and illustrate advantages, disadvantages, and validity.

sec.title: Summary of current multiscale manufacturing processes
sec.p:
Some of the more widely used methods for manufacturing conventional composite parts are vacuum-assisted resin transfer molding (VaRTM), resin transfer molding (RTM), resin film infusion (RFI), Seemann composite resin infusion molding process (SCRIMP), autoclave processing, hand lay-up, wet/spray lay-up, pultrusion, filament winding, prepreg method, and fiber placement technology, amongst others.64 One method that is being strenuously evaluated and practiced in manufacturing multiscale composite parts is the addition of the CNTs in the polymer resin prior to its curing, solidification, shaping, and hardening called resin “doping”. VaRTM is a variation of the RTM process and is a commonly used single-sided tooling process utilized to make parts employing vacuum pressure.64 VaRTM, as illustrated in Figure 9, is a process for molding FRC structures in which a sheet of flexible transparent material such as nylon or Mylar plastic is placed over the preform on the mold and sealed. Figure 9.
Vacuum-assisted resin transfer molding (VaRTM) lay-up illustration.

A vacuum is applied to the system; the entrapped air between the bagging film and the preform layers is removed. A catalyst is then mixed into the resin vat. The vacuum and voided air draws in the catalyzed resin and impregnates (infuse/wets) the fibers. The flow of resin during an infusion process is given by Darcy’s Law: (8)Q=kAηdPdx where Q is flow rate across a section A, η is the resin viscosity, k is the preform permeability, and dP/dx is the pressure gradient.65 There are two regions in terms of permeability and porosity in woven preforms where the final properties are based. These regions are referred to as micro- and bulk-regions. The micro-region is the low permeability region within the fiber tow, while the bulk-region is the higher permeability region between the fiber tows. The difference in permeability could lead to incomplete saturation of the preform.66

The most common VaRTM techniques utilize longitudinal and transverse flows of the liquid matrix with surface porous distribution media/material, as shown in Figure 10. In the first case, resin flows longitudinally between the preform layers, where the permeability is higher than in the preform itself, as seen in Figure 10(a). It is usually employed for fabrication of small parts where the injection length is short. In the second case, resin is distributed transversely through a highly permeable distribution media, sometimes referred to as flow media, which is placed on top of the preform layers. Due to its high permeability, resin flows longitudinally through the flow media first and then saturates the preforms’ inter-tow and intra-tow43 spacing by means of a transverse flow through the thickness of the preform layers, as illustrated in Figure 10(b).66 Very large parts may be fabricated using VaRTM and inducing its transverse flow dynamics. This process is sometimes referred to as Seemann composite resin infusion molding process (SCRIMP).64,67 Figure 10.
Vacuum-assisted resin transfer molding (VaRTM): (a) longitudinal flow and (b) transverse flow illustrating flow front through the thickness of performs laminates.

Upon complete wet out, the system can be clamped for curing and the part can be placed in an oven to post cure. The addition of further pressure (autoclave) results in higher fiber fractions and provides better adhesion between layers.

The VaRTM process is among the forefront of multiscale manufacturing processes utilizing a doped resin system. Hsiao and Gangireddy.68 used the VaRTM process to manufacture L-shaped composite structures, as illustrated in Figure 11, to investigate the effect of dispersed CNF in an attempt to reduce part distortions after demolding. The dimensions of the final part were approximately 137.25 cm2 or 8.375 in2. Figure 11.
Demolded and trimmed L-shape composite.68

Qiu et al. fabricated multifunctional multiscale composites through impregnation-based VaRTM processes.43 CNT-dispersed resins were made to flow through intra-tows and inter-tows of fiber, resulting in interlaminar reinforcement provided from MWNTs. The tensile tests and short-beam tests demonstrated that both the modulus and strength were improved with only 1 wt% of functionalized MWNTs. Specifically, the through-thickness properties of the multifunctional composite were effectively improved when compared to the performance of traditional composites. The MWNTs in the through-thickness direction of composites enhanced the mechanical properties without compromising the in-plane properties.43 Kim et al. produced epoxy/carbon fiber/CNT multiscale composite panels using sonication and VaRTM. A small loading of CNTs (0.3 wt% with respect to the resin/curing agent mixture) had little influence on the fiber-dominated tensile properties, while it enhanced the matrix-dominated flexural properties significantly. It was demonstrated that CNTs can serve as an efficient filler material that can reinforce the matrix at a small loading. However, SEM analysis revealed weak bonding at the matrix–fiber–nanotube interfaces, suggesting that load transferability has room for improvement.7

Figure 12 shows the RTM process, which is a closed mold operation64 and has also employed the use of doped resin for multiscale composite manufacture. The dry fiber reinforcements are set up in the mold in the form of woven cloth format, random-continuous strand mat or binder-bound chopped mat. After the fibers are installed into the mold, a premixed catalyst and resin/doped rein is injected into the closed mold cavity encompassing the fiber within. Figure 12.
Resin transfer molding (RTM).

In this process, resin flow and fiber wet-out are critical issues; resin flows in the plane as well as in the transverse directions of the preform. Fiber wet-out depends on the fiber architecture and permeability of the preform. Recent developments in textile and resin technology have allowed designers and manufacturers to use RTM for fabricating parts for both primary (skeletal or frame) and secondary structures (enclosures).69 Advanced textile technology has helped to increase the wetability of the preforms.19 Higher toughness can be achieved by using three-dimensional weaving and stitching technology. However, in both RTM and VaRTM processes resin flow is more difficult at higher viscosities prevalent in CNT-doped resin systems. The effects of nanoconstituents on the matrix resins create a problem in the altered resin viscosity and cure kinetics,70 resulting in the possibility of dry spots or uneven distribution of resin over the entire volume of the reinforcement.71 In experiments performed by Cheng et al.,72 where they set out to fabricate CNT preforms with macroscopic sizes by stacking aligned and continuous CNT sheets drawn from super-aligned CNT arrays, the viscosity of the epoxy resin was about 50 cPa at 60°C and the pressure gradient was ∼0.2 MPa. As the number of CNT sheets increased to 6000, the permeability of the CNT preform became too low to allow the epoxy infuse into the space between the CNTs. Methods for improving the permeability of the CNT preforms and decreasing the viscosity of the epoxy were reported to need further investigation. Higher CNT volume fractions tend to result in lower permeability and flow rate of the resin and thus fail to make a CNT/epoxy composite by the RTM process.

Resin film infusion (RFI), shown in Figure 13, is comparable to RTM in which a thin film or sheet of solid resin is laid into the mold and preform fibers are laid on top of the resin film under applied heat and pressure. Resin impregnated unidirectional or woven fabric (partially cured) is used in the prepreg method with vacuum bagging and autoclave processing. Although the method is labor intensive, resin distribution in its preforms are usually uniform.19 Figure 13.
Resin film infusion diagram.

Hand and wet/spray lay-ups are simple open mold methods compared to other composite manufacturing methods. Hand lay-up begins by positioning the fiber in or on the mold by hand. If the mold has complex geometrical features, small pieces of mat are cut to fit and then more layers are applied to achieve the required thickness. The liquid resin is then poured over the fiber/fiber layers and rolled to ensure complete wetting of the fiber and removal of air bubbles, as shown in Figure 14(a) Wet/spray lay-up is a more semi-automated process. It begins by applying an optional gel coat to the mold. A chopper gun equipped with an air-pressurized resin pump, catalyst reservoir, and fiber feeder is then utilized to spray coat the mold as shown in Figure 14(b). Figure 14.
(a) Hand lay-up (b) wet/spray lay-up illustration.

In general, the resin cures at room temperature with the use of an accelerator and a catalyst. If a hot cure is used, an accelerator is not required. This method allows the resin to be applied only in the mold, but the mechanical properties of the product are poor due to voids, and the final product tends to be non-uniform. Chowdhury et al.73 fabricated woven carbon/epoxy laminates using hand lay-up with the epoxy modified using Nanomer® I-28E nanoclay, an organically modified clay at different weight percentages. Flexural test results of thermally post-cured samples indicate a maximum improvement in strength and modulus of about 31% and 21%, respectively, as dictated in Table 1 and illustrated in Figure 15. They also deemed 2 wt% nanoclay to be an optimum loading for carbon/SC-15 epoxy composites in terms of mechanical and thermal properties.30,74 Figure 15.
Flexural stress–strain plot of post cured hand-layup samples.74 Table 1.
Flexural test results of thermally post cured hand lay-up samples.74
Flexural Strength, MPa % Gain/ Loss in strength Flexural Modulus, GPa % Gain/Loss in modulus
Control sample 380 ± 3.3 – 37.57 ± 0.77 –
1% Nanoclay 426 ± 10.81 12.10 43.8 ± 2. 13 16.58
2% Nanoclay 493 ± 12 31 31.05 45.6 ± 0.81 21.37
3% Nanoclay 446 ± 8. 95 17.36 46.9 ± 1.22 24.8

Recent interest and advances of VaRTM yielded another process known as resin infusion between double flexible tooling (RIDFT), which is a derivation of the RIFT process that was being considered as a clean alternative to hand lay-up as far back as 1950, and then referred to as “The Marco method”. It was designed for the manufacture of boat hulls to reduced voids and tooling costs when compared to RTM. The Marco tooling design utilized dry reinforcement that was laid up onto the solid male tool and a semi-flexible/splash female tool was used for consolidation and to provide a seal for the application of vacuum which can be seen in Figure 16.75 Figure 16.
The macro method of resin infusion under flexible tooling (RIFT) (circa 1950).75

Fast-forward 50 years and the RIDFT method and apparatus developed by Thagard et al.76 takes center stage. The RIDFT method, as seen in Figure 17 is a novel two-stage process, which incorporates resin infusion and wetting with vacuum forming. After placing the mold in the vacuum chamber, the bottom sealing frame and attached flexible diaphragm (silicone sheet) are set in place. The dry fiber preforms are then laid flat onto the silicone sheet followed by its covering using the top sealing frame and attached flexible diaphragm (silicone sheet). Figure 17.
Resin infusion between double flexible tooling.

The system is then infused with resin two dimensionally until complete wet-out. Subsequently, the vacuum pulls the flexible diaphragms and inter-lain fibers down and is conformed over the mold. Once curing is achieved, the vacuum is released and the part removed. The flow front of the infused resin being two-dimensional avoids flow complexities prevalent in three-dimensional flow seen in other liquid composite molding techniques. Utilizing CNT-doped resin Parker et al.77 were able to fabricate sizable “C”-shaped carbon fiber parts at up to 2 wt% CNT-doped vinyl-ester resin. They were able to infuse viscous resins at about 10,000 cPs using specialized flow distribution channels.

Pultrusion is a continuous process for manufacturing composite materials with constant cross-sections. This process begins as individual reinforced fiber strands from fiber creels are brought together and passed through a guide plate. This conglomeration of fiber strands (fiber tow) is then guided by a series of rollers through a resin/doped resin bath and subsequent preformer then forming and curing die to culminate at a cut-off saw. Many resin types may be used in pultrusion including polyester, polyurethane, vinyl ester, and epoxy. Pultrusion, as illustrated in Figure 18, is a low-cost continuous process with a high production rate for manufacturing linear composite parts. Figure 18.
Pultrusion process.

The fibers in pultruded materials are generally well aligned,78 which helps to reduce fiber misalignment in the composite by optimizing the manufacturing process variables, such as pull-speed, preformer temperature, nanoparticle alignment, and/or dispersion. Hussain et al.79 studied the compressive strength of pultruded thermoplastic composites containing 5 and 10 wt% nanoclay reinforcement and observed consistent improvements in the compressive strength and modulus up to about 122% at 10% clay loading. Further, the test data indicate that it is feasible to pultrude nanoclay-reinforced E-glass–polypropylene (PP) laminates with up to 27% fiber volume fraction and up to 10% nanoclay content without a deleterious increase in resin viscosity that could clog the consolidation die and/or result in poor wetting of the fibers. Along with clogging or the accumulation of materials that could occur near the die causing jams, voids may also be created if the dies run with too large an opening to the fiber volume input. Moreover, a constant cross section is a disadvantage limiting this process.

In filament winding, as illustrated in Figure 19, resin-impregnated fibers are wrapped over a mandrel at the same or different winding angles to form a part. Complicated cylindrical parts can be manufactured using this method. The viscosity-related problems of the resin systems can be eliminated in this technique due to the absence of batch flow wetting. This is due to the fact that this process guides continuous individual fiber strands through a resin/CNT doped bath prior to cylindrical part wrapping, but the critical task is programming the wet winding in this technique.19 Figure 19.
Filament winding diagram.80

A method for dispersing SWNTs in epoxy was investigated by Spindler-Ranta and Bakis.81 Arc-produced SWNTs were dispersed in bisphenol A epoxy resin and triamine hardener with the aid of a surfactant. They used a high-power ultrasound to produce CNTs reinforced epoxy, which could then be used in filament winding. Filament winding is a cost-effective alternative for fabricating spherical and cylindrical parts, even those with varying diameters and surface contours. However, the drawback is that it cannot lay tow on a concave surface.82

Advanced structural applications require incorporating nanoreinforcements into macroscopic functions and validating them at the nanometric level. Recently, nanocomposites have been introduced in structural applications, such as automotive parts, gas barrier films, scratch-resistant coating, and flame-retardant cables. Additionally, RTM, VaRTM, RFI, and filament winding techniques can be used to manufacture nanocomposite parts for various applications including commercial aircraft structures for Boeing and Airbus, as well as many products in the industrial markets. Routine use of nanocomposites in automotive and aerospace industries is a long-term prospect as these are risk-averse sectors and extensive testing and characterization alone takes significant time.19,37

sec.title: Challenges in current methodologies
sec.p: A variety of nanoparticles may be used to improve the properties of the polymeric phase. CNTs are mainly used due to their excellent mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties.17,18,83–85 Nanoscale fibers such as CNTs can be introduced into the polymer matrix region (order of 1 µm spacing) between existing micron-diameter fibers to reinforce the laminate. Works with CNTs and other nanomaterials have either focused solely on the interlaminar area or have dispersed small quantities (by volume) of unaligned CNTs within the resin matrix via mixing or other methods for intralaminar reinforcement. Due to significant issues with agglomeration, lack of alignment, poor dispersion, and damage to CNTs during mixing, only marginal mechanical property improvements are observed for both nanocomposites45 and hybrid composites25–27 when CNTs are mixed into the bulk matrix. Somewhat more success has been achieved with nanoscale modifications of the interlaminar region (between plies), either by growing CNTs on the surface of cloth42 or placing unaligned CNTs at low volume fraction at the interface.29–32 An area of particular activity has been the growth of CNTs on the surface of carbon fibers. Nonetheless, the typical CNT growth processes significantly damage tensile properties of the carbon fibers.33–36

Bekyarova et al.5 suggested electrophoresis as being an efficient technique for the uniform deposition of CNTs on the surface of carbon fabric, which can be seen as the small white strands in Figure 20. Their carbon nanotube/carbon fiber preforms were successfully infiltrated with epoxy resin using the VaRTM method. They believe that this can lead to multiscale hybrid composites with enhanced out-of-plane mechanical and electrical properties. They also suggest that the electrophoretic deposition process is readily scalable for industrial applications and may be further explored for the development of advanced structural composites. However, this method was only tested on carbon fabrics and may not prove as effective when utilized on other fabric preforms.5,86 Figure 20.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of carbon fibers (CFs) with (a) single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) and (b, c) multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) deposited by electrophoresis. The CFs shown in panels (a) and (b) were annealed in vacuum and treated with nitric acid, whereas the CFs in panel (c) were used as-received.5,86

sec.title: Problems currently existing in the manufacture of multiscale composites
sec.p:
One of the main barriers to the widespread use of composites is an efficient mass-production process. As discussed previously, traditional manufacturing techniques, such as hand layup are slow, labor intensive, and may be harmful to personnel health and the environment. Even processes as filament winding are only suitable to relatively simple geometries. CNTs have the potential to improve the mechanical, physical, and electrical properties of polymers.37,38 They exhibit an exceptionally high aspect ratio in combination with low density,40 as well as high strength and stiffness,5 which makes them a potential candidate for the reinforcement of polymeric materials. The key point is to transfer the potential mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties of the CNTs to the polymer composite.32 Numerous efforts have focused on integrating nanotubes into polymer matrices.18,87,88 In spite of the enormous interest CNTs have attracted as potential reinforcements for lightweight structural composites, their performance so far has been inadequate. This is attributed by many experts to four issues:
Difficulty of dispersing the CNTs in the matrix due to the fact that they tend to stick together,
Only small amounts of CNTs (1–5 wt%) have been used so far due to processing difficulties,
Insufficient bonding at the nanotubes/matrix interface resulting in matrix debonding or pull out,2 and
The difficulty of aligning the tubes within the matrix.

Although the four listed issues have yet to be resolved, extensive efforts are underway to overcome them. For example, it has been reported that extruding the composite as a thin film and drawing the film prior to cooling can achieve alignment of CNTs in a polymer matrix.9 Issues with CNT dispersion have been addressed by a number of methods including sonication and by shear forces during the melt processing of the CNT dispersion solution mixture.18,89 Depending on the matrix, different solvents have been used to disperse the nanotubes. For example, acetone, dimethylformamide (DMF) and methanol have been used to disperse CNTs in epoxy-based composites,89 whereas tetrahydrofuran (THF) has been used with polystyrene.2 However, the solvents have been observed to influence the mechanical performance of the composite;89 therefore, other dispersion techniques need to be investigated. A strong nanotube–matrix interface can reportedly be achieved by nanotube surface treatment or by modifying the polymer to provide functional groups that can bond the nanotube and the matrix strongly together.90

Fiedler et al.32 have found and shown that CNTs can often become entwined as a result of the production process; however, they need to be well dispersed in the composite matrix to become viable constituents. The degree or magnitude of entanglement depends on the type of CNT utilized and the manufacturing process performed. Catalytically grown MWCNTs contain fewer impurities (e.g., amorphous carbon) as shown in Figure 21(a) than arc-grown MWCNTs depicted in Figure 21(b).91 However, catalytically grown MWCNTs also contain a higher defect density. Figure 21.
Micrographs of different types of carbon nanotubes (CNTs). (a) Catalytically grown multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) from Nanocyl SA (Belgium);32,91 (b) rod-like arc-grown MWNTs from TUHH.

The cotton-like appearance of the nanotube formation is due to the manufacturing process. In the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) process, the CNTs grow onto a catalyst covered substrate plate, where, other than a high entanglement, a generally parallel orientation of the nanotubes can be achieved. As they are relatively long and have a high aspect ratio, they can be easily interpenetrated as evident in Figure 22(a). In contrast to arc-grown nanotubes, which have a low-defect density and appear as straight, rod-like structures as shown in Figure 21(b); CVD-nanotubes occasionally form irregular pentagons and heptagons alongside the nanotubes or exhibit imperfections in the graphite lattice, which lead to structural bends. Figure 22.
Micrographs of different types of carbon nanotubes (CNTs): (a) scanning electron microscopy (SEM)-image of chemical vapor deposition (CVD)-multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) from Nanocyl, which exhibit a highly entangled appearance; (b) catalytically grown double-walled carbon nanotubes (DWNTs) as produced from Nanocyl SA (Belgium).32,92

The DWCNTs shown in Figure 22(b) and SWCNTs again have a very high aspect ratio, leading to the cotton-like structure already described for MWCNTs in Figure 22(a). Additionally, they form strands of bundles, called nanoropes, in which the CNTs parallelize due to attracting van der Waals forces. This reduced length can be explained in terms of the functionalization. Various methods can be used to place functional groups onto the CNT surfaces, either by chemical reactions, such as oxidation, or by mechanical treatment inducing further chemical reactions, such as ball-milling in amines. Any kind of functionalization induces changes in the CNT-structure.

Another technique involves growing the CNTs as coils, using a reduced pressure CVD method, thus taking advantage of nanomechanical interlocking and minimizing inter-tube slipping.89 Researchers have also grown nanotubes from CF with the aim of enhancing the bonding between the CF and the matrix. For example, Thostenson et al.93 grew CNTs directly on CF using a CVD and thus forming a hybrid, multiscale composite. The load transfer was found to improve as a result of local stiffening due to the nanotubes at the fiber/matrix interface. More creative processing techniques are needed. Although the CVD process is an efficient technique for the growth of CNTs on a variety of surfaces, the use of high temperatures and predeposited catalysts, taken together with the difficulties in processing large panels, imposes serious limitations on the practical application of this technique for the fabrication of CNT-reinforced structural composites. Furthermore, high-temperature processing with CVD removes any sizing that may be applied to the fiber during manufacturing; and the CVD reaction may also degrade the fiber strength.5 In this context, two main issues must be solved to effectively improve the material properties of polymers by adding CNTs as fillers. These issues are the interfacial bonding, and especially the proper dispersion of the individual CNTs in the polymeric matrix. Wagner et al. focused on interfacial bonding.94 They performed pull-out experiments of individual CNTs embedded in a polymer matrix with a specially developed test in order to evaluate the interfacial shear strength of the nanotube polymer system. The interfacial adhesion to the polymer can be enhanced by chemical functionalization of the nanotube surface.32 MD simulations by Gates et al.95 predicted an influence of chemical bonding between the nanotubes and the matrix on the interfacial adhesion.

sec.title: Dispersion
sec.p:
The dispersion of the CNTs in the matrix system has been found to be quite challenging and limiting in the production of multiscale composites. Nanoscaled particles exhibit an enormous surface area being several orders of magnitude larger than the surface of conventional fillers. In the case of particles and fibers, the surface area per unit volume is inversely proportional to the material’s diameter, thus, the smaller the diameter, the greater the surface area per unit volume,96 as seen in Figure 23. A nanostructured material can have substantially different properties from a larger-dimensional material of the same composition.19 Figure 23.
Surface area to volume ratio as a function of particle diameter.97

This surface area acts as crossing point for stress transfer but is also accountable for the high propensity of the CNTs to form agglomerates. The properties of conventional composites are controlled by the constitutive mechanical, electrical, and optical properties of fiber, matrix, and interface. Producing high-performance nanocomposites requires for a variety of challenges to be overcome. The balance of various interactions must be first understood and then can be characterized by the properties of the particle types being investigated, the matrix materials, and in particular the manufacturing process being utilized. To evenly distribute the CNTs in the matrix polymer, as shown in Figure 24, five parameters have to be controlled: length of the nanotubes, their entanglement, volume fraction, the high matrix viscosity, and the tube/tube attraction (mainly for SWCNT and double walled CNTs (DWCNT)).32 Figure 24(a) and (b) portrays a cross-sectional view of a fiber-influenced matrix-enriched area and its enlarged perspective depicting CNTs as small white strands. Figure 24.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of multiscale composites’ polymer matrix and fiber region: (a) 1% multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWNT)-dispersed composites and (b) 3% MWNT-dispersed composites.

However, the use of these nanosize fillers or nanofillers could be limited by dispersion problems and viscosity build-up related to strong inter-particle interactions.83,98–100 The potential particle distribution depends on the particle type and size, the specific surface area (SSA), the volume content of particles, and the mixing conditions.98,99 The particle volume content plays a very important role, but the interphase between the matrix and the particles plays an even major role.98 A large number of nanoparticles yields a large surface area, and the resulting nanocomposite is interface-dominated.98,99 By increasing the CNT length, the resulting interactive forces, similar to the influence of the molecular weight (chain length), hinders the separation of the nanotubes. The shear forces introduced into the suspension in order to separate the agglomerates and to disperse the individual CNTs is controlled by the manufacturing process. To disperse the nanotubes various methods can be used: (A) sonication, (B) stirring, and (C) calendaring.

sec.title: (A) Sonication
sec.p:
Ultrasonic devices have a locally focused high impact of energy but introduce low portion of shear forces, hence making this method only suitable for very low viscous matrix materials and small volumes. Furthermore, the effectiveness regarding the dispersion has to be regarded as limited. Additionally, the local introduction of the energy may lead to rupture and damage of CNTs, reducing the overall aspect ratio. An effective way to apply the sonication technique to produce CNT-nanocomposites is to disperse them in an appropriate solvent (i.e., acetone), as illustrated in Figure 25, which first allows the agglomerates to be separated due to vibration energy.101 Figure 25.
Sonication illustration.

The suspension can later be mixed with the resin, while simply heating removes the solvent via evaporation. In an experiment by He et al., MWCNTs were sonicated for 20 min at 30% amplitude, mixed with the epoxy resin and again sonicated for 10 min, yet, agglomerates were still present. For nanotubes exhibiting a much larger SSA, like DWCNTs, the agglomerates are much bigger. During this sonication process, the samples need to be cooled to avoid the untimely cure of the composite. Finally, the composites were cured following the manufacturers regulations. A reduction of the agglomerate size may be achieved with a functionalization process.102 The functional groups, which develop on the surfaces on the CNTs, lead to steric hindering and electrostatic interactions with the solvent, leading to a better distribution of the CNTs in the epoxy matrix.32

sec.title: (B) Stirring
sec.p: Stirring is a common technique to disperse particles in liquid systems and can be used as well to disperse nanoparticles. The size and shape of the propeller and the mixing speed control the dispersion result. After intensive stirring of MWCNTs in an epoxy resin, a relatively fine dispersion can be achieved.101 The MWCNTs can be distributed more easily than DW- and SWCNTs; however, they have a tendency to re-agglomerate. This experimentally observed flocculation behavior is mainly caused by frictional contacts and elastic interlocking mechanisms.103 Other parameters, like sliding forces and weak attractive forces, have only little effect on the flocculation during stirring. In case of the much thinner DW- and SWCNTs, higher shear forces are needed to achieve a fine dispersion.13

sec.title: (C) Calendaring
sec.p:
The 3-roll mill has been used extensively in the dispersion of CNTs and nanoparticles.92,101,104 This method is an established and common technique to disperse micro-particles in different matrices, such as color pigments for cosmetics or lacquers. A major advantage of this method, besides the improved dispersion results, is the efficient manufacturing of larger nanocomposites. The calendaring mill depicted in Figure 26 shows an illustration of a 3-roll mill, which are usually used to disperse the nanomaterials by controlling the gap sizes (δ) and the rotational speeds (ω). Figure 26.
Schematic drawing of 3-roll mill; ω1, ω2 are speeds of rollers 1 and 2; δg is the roller gap.105

Several passes are usually required, with each successive pass made with a reduced gap size (δ). Fiedler et al. utilized this method for experimentation in which a gap size between the aluminum rolls was set around 5 µm. Then the speed was set to 20 rounds per minute (r/min) (first roll), 60 r/min (second roll), and 180 r/min (third roll). Upon introducing the liquid matrix suspension into the system, the dwell time of each batch of suspension on the rolls was in the range of minutes. An initial primary dispersion of the agglomerates was performed in the knead vortexes, whereas the final distribution of the nanoparticles occurs in the thin gap between the rolls. The suspension was then collected and mixed with the hardener for 10 minutes by intense stirring, infused into a VaRTM system, and cured for 24 hours at room temperature (RT) and finally post-cured at 60°C for 24 hours. The hardener was added, followed by further processing of the composite according to the manufacturer’s requirements, yielding the final level of dispersion. From Figure 27(a) and (b) the high quality of the dispersion can be seen. Only a few small aggregates remain, which are smeared out and well penetrated by the epoxy matrix.32 Figure 27.
Typical transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrographs of carbon nanotube (CNT)/epoxy composites: (a) calendaring of multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWNT)/epoxy; (b) calendaring of double-walled carbon nanotube (DWNT)/epoxy.32

sec.title: Flow
sec.p: High shear rates can exfoliate the MWNT aggregates, and some researchers have achieved reasonable MWNT dispersion using high shear rates in an extruder.89,106 Thus, one would expect high shear rates to be generated due to the small gaps that may affect the dispersion of the CNT in the composite. Thus, the final MWNT/glass fiber structure will be affected by the initial MWNT dispersion state and the porous media structure. The flow of the MWNT suspension through the glass fiber porous architecture is an interesting and important issue in fabrication of such hybrid composites and is being explored for the first time.

Manufacturing CNT-polymer composites requires low-viscosity resins which allow particles to be organized within the resin. However, the high SSA of CNTs encourages the formation of agglomerates due to intermolecular interactions, such as van der Waals forces. In order to suppress the agglomeration, a control of surface polarity and resulting interactive forces between particles and matrix is needed. The infiltration of the carbon nanotube/fiber panels with resin is a difficult task because the addition of CNTs to the fiber layers results in a drastic increase in the reinforcement surface area, and it can impede the infusion of the fiber bundles and thus slower permeation and flow.

sec.title: Filtration
sec.p: Fabricating M-FRCs using modified resins have some limitations which hinder their development. Many of those limitations are related to homogeneously distributing the nanoparticles throughout the bulk of the composite.14 Some of the critical challenges for the future development of M-FRCs are to integrate, control, and exploit the nanoparticle and its properties within hierarchal structural composites made using commercially viable processing methods. There have been few reports investigating M-FRC systems that have a CNF/epoxy nanophased polymer matrix with woven glass fiber fabric geometries. Reports exist on the synthesis and fabrication of M-FRCs using glass fiber preforms infused with a low viscosity CNF/epoxy nanophased polymer matrix, with the overall goal being to investigate the: (a) matrix-dominant mechanical properties using flexural and ILSS tests; (b) relaxation behavior (Tg) and (iii) dimensional stability (CTE) of the M-FRCs.15 For example, when fabricating M-FRCs using the VARIM process, nanoparticles can become filtered, resulting in an inhomogeneous microstructure.16 This filtering is caused by the nanoparticles being trapped in inter-tow regions within the fiber preform mesh during fabrication.

Filtering, as illustrated in Figure 28, is more apparent when using nanoparticles that have high-aspect ratios like CNFs and CNTs.21 Figure 28.
Reinforcing fabrics act as filters, preventing the flow of carbon nanotubes (CNTs).43

Parker et al.77 reported on the use of the RIDFT process to overcome the flow and filtration problems associated with the infusion of CNT-doped resin systems. Their use of an optimized flow distribution channel allowed the uninhibited flow of resin at viscosities around 10,000 cPs. Figure 29 shows C-shaped glass-CNT multiscale composites with 1 wt% CNTs, manufactured using the RIDFT process. Although the reported process is said to be able to infuse large parts, the system as with other techniques allows end-to-end infusion of doped resins. This means that CNTs or other nanomaterials will be distributed through the matrix even if this is not desirable or expensive. Figure 29.
C-shaped glass fiber laminate infused with 1 wt% carbon nanotube (CNT) doped vinyl-ester resin.77

sec.title: Selective placement for CNT infusion
sec.p: General selective placement of CNTs has been considered and utilized through practices such as prepreg implementation and CVD. Abot et al.85 fabricated a nanoreinforced laminated composite (NRLC) utilizing arrays of aligned MWCNT, with a tailored thickness in the micron range, synthesized with an EasyTube® CVD system that can grow arrays on 300-mm wafers. They consider their MWCNT arrays with a thickness in the range of 50–500 µm are being for the reinforcement of the laminated composites. Initially, 5-mm-thick NRLC specimens are being formed with an MWCNT array (25 × 12 × 0.5 mm), a polyacrilonitrile-based carbon woven fabric (plain weave), and a Bisphenol-A amine-cured epoxy polymer.

Once the plies comprising the carbon woven fabric with the impregnated MWCNT arrays are prepared, the laminated composite is fabricated by stacking them with a press molding technique to cure the polymer. The laminated composites panels that were prepared with this technique are relatively small (less than 50 mm by 50 mm) and have slightly lower properties than those prepared from prepreg materials. Their claim as one of the significant features of the NRLC is its ability to carry large nanoparticle contents. More than 10% nanoparticle concentrations are easy to achieve, and even higher ones are possible with higher consolidation pressures during the lamination process. However, current processes, through which CNTs are integrated, are time consuming, can be hazardous, and often require a high technical knowledge/skill level, limiting the number of qualified handlers. This in turn can hinder and slow productivity. Additionally, the processes may yield undesirable results; for example, voids weaken areas of the composite; filtration impedes the complete impregnation of CNTs within the desired part; non-uniform dispersion gives way to a variation in the material properties over the area of the composite; and waste is evident when non-desired CNT-enriched areas are infused. This makes manufacturing through resin infusion difficult with many researchers resorting to open-mold techniques. Additionally, current techniques mostly result in the placement of CNTs throughout the entire laminates, rather than in selected areas. Moreover, manufactured dimensionality is limited as nano inclusion concentrations are increased. Thus, most reported specimen successes are laboratory-specific and un-applicable in large-scale applications. Table 2 dictates the primary need for increased multiscale manufacturing methods by illustrating the limited area of fabricated laminates currently available for reproduction. Subsequently, these are the main barriers to the widespread use of CNT applied composites deeming an efficient mass-producible manufacturing process a goal for the future of multiscale FRCs. Table 2.

sec.title: Displaced Foam Dispersion Technique
sec.p: The displaced foam dispersion (DFD) technique is acclaimed to provide an efficient and robust method for reinforcing fibers with CNTs.107 To date, most of the relevant development efforts have been done on a small scale or at the component level due to the limitations on the current capacity of CNT production and its associated costs. This makes the development of a scalable method for the cost-effective production of multiscale laminates imperative. One such technique under development is the DFD technique, which uses a carrier foam system to achieve the selective placement of highly loaded and dispersed nanomaterials within multiscale composites.

In the DFD process, sheets of foam encapsulating the nanomaterials are placed between layers of reinforcing fabrics, as seen in Figure 30. As resin is infused, the foam carrier system is dissolved and becomes part of the resin system, leaving the nanomaterials where required by design. Figure 30.
Schematic of the displaced foam dispersion (DFD) process.

The viability of the technique is still under scrutiny, with several aspects still subject to research. A better understanding of the process variables is required to allow for the complete removal of the foam carrier system. Furthermore, additional study is necessary to determine how the nanomaterials behave during the foaming process and how they lie (or come to rest) after foam depletion.

sec.title: Conclusion and new focus
sec.p: The implementation of nanoscale particles as a strengthening and conducting agent in the matrix of FRCs is a currently evolving science incorporating various methods from CNT resin doping to CNT fiber growing. Several works have reported the rising advantages, benefits, and gains, citing improvements through experimentation. However, these and other methods are only moderately efficient and feasible on small-scale applications. Hand/wet layup and LCM processes such as RIM, VARTM, RTM, RIDFT are among the forefront of multiscale manufacturing. Dispersion, flow, and filtration continue to present challenges that hinder the growth and application of multiscale composites in out-of-lab structures. The ability to harness the advantages of multiscale composites firmly lie in the scalability and cost effectiveness of manufacturing processes that allow for their efficient production. As such, it is imperative that researchers begin to address this prevalent functional gap. Additionally, it will be beneficial to address issues such as: selective placement which would aid in material waste elimination, tailorability to allow for more widespread use and multifunctional applications, and handleability for safety and environmental effectiveness. Overcoming the challenges and actualizing the potential benefits from further insights will yield advancement in the field and increasing growth for multifunctional multiscale composite manufacturing.

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
